text: BRIEF REPORT BEHAVIORAL SELF-HELP MATERIALS AS AN ADJUNCT TO NICOTINE GUM
The present study assessed the incremental effectivenesk of.behavioral self-help materials specifically written to accompany nicotine gum.
Subjects (187 women and I17 men) were randomly assigned either behavioral self-help booklets oi a factual information pamphlet.
All subjects received prescriptions for Nicorette@ from Study physicians.
Contrary to prediction, subjects provided self-help booklets fared no bed&r than did subjects provided comparison pamphlets.
Overall abstinence levels were encouraging, however.
Nicotine gum users were far more likely than nonusers to maintain abstinence through 6 - month follow-up.
Perhaps self-help materials could be improved by condensing and simplifying content and by adopting a more attractive multicolored pictorial format.
Study results were disappointing in that they failed to indicate the specific effectiveness of behavioral self-help materials written to accompany nicotine gum.
Overall abstinence figures were considerably more encouraging.
Attaining a 20.1% 12 - month abstinence level with a program limited to nicotine gum and written information is impressive.
However, these abstinence figures represent prevalance outcomes rather than continuous abstinence.
Furthermore, an adjustment must be made for an approximately 10% rate of false reporting.
Interviews with both patients and study physicians suggested a general lack of physician adherence in following the study protocol.
This was true despite the fact that these physicians were a selected sample who volunteered to participate in a research endeavor.
The study may have been significantly affected by the fact that it was conducted prior to the general availability of Nicorette.
Although the majority of study physicians limited subjects to their own patients, prospective subjects from a radius of 200 to 300 miles requested the opportunity to receive nicotine gum.

The relatively favorable abstinence results are somewhat surprising in light of the habituated nature of the study sample, the fact that some patients were simply enrolled by physicians who ordered them to quit, and the fact that Nicorette was provided at no charge.
It is perhaps noteworthy that despite free gum, 87 of 304 patients reported failing to chew even a single piece.
This may have been at least in part a function of limited physician advice and instructions.
Study materials might have been improved by streamlining information and by adopting a more attractive multicolored format.
Patients may have been overwhelmed with excessive content and may have found the wording overly academic.
Follow-up interviews with patients suggested that both factors were operating.
Future work should emphasize Nicorette as an adjunct to quitting smoking.
Gum is not a substitute for cigarettes.
When properly used, Nicorette can lessen withdrawal and can assist the individual's other coping techniques.
Outcome should be enhanced if physicians or office staff instruct patients more fully and then inquire about their smoking status at future visits.
